reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is about symbolism, I assume.

As a kid, you jump from piece to piece on a bridge to get a gigantic donut, but at the beginning area, there's a bench and a trash can.

As an adult, you see a normal street filled with people trying to crossin one direction. There's a bench and a trash can where you begin.

As an old man, you are at the same street, only lonlier and more unforgiving. It's difficult to turn, and the bench and trash can are still there.

You can tell that the kid used imagination to cross the road, and you can tell that as an adult and old man, it becomes much more gray and realistic. It basically shows you perspectives, and about how each one can affect mood or emotions.

As for the gameplay, there's no shooting, no puzzles, no free-roam. It's just walking around. The Way of Life is a game about teaching, not providing an amazing gameplay.

So overall, this game was great. It instantly brought me back to my youth, and how I thought all of the lines at my school was lava, and that I had to jump over it. Once I grew up, I started to step on the lines like they weren't a big deal. The game shows the gradual progression of how innocence can turn into realism and logic over the course of everyday life. I think it was a great game, considering the people that made this only had 24 hours.

I rate 9/10, great symbolism.

Early Access Review

I honestly really enjoyed this game for what it was, which is giving the experience of life from a range of different ages. This game is not for those who want something that they can spend mindless hours playing, and the finished game will most likely not be like that either. This game is meant for those who want a new perspective on things, that will provoke them into thinking about what life is like. I'm earnestly looking forward to what the developers will include when the full game is completed.

Spoilers below, avert your eyes if you haven't played the game yet!

This game attempts to emulate living, by providing three stages.

For businessmen, you're in complete control, but life is dull and boring, just doing the daily grind for your paycheck. You don't have any friends, just fellow humans all living the day-to-day life of corporate America.

The old man is nearing his end, and is losing the ability to even walk. He sways his head as he checks the road, the cars oblivious to his presence. A bench seems to emerge out of the fog, beckoning him to take a rest before he continues his endeavor.

Children, full of energy, see life, every day, as an adventure. He jumps with joy, hardly able to contain his excitement as he approaches Sugar Realm. But first, he must face the challenge of dragons, hampering every step up the treacherous bridge. One wrong move, and he could plummet into the lava below.

I think that these perspectives, although stereotypical, give an accurate look into the minds of people and their outlook on the world. It really helps to go into this with an attitude of an open mind, restraining any expectations you might have.

Early Access Review

The Way Of Life is a free to play, first person, indie game currently in early access as I'm writing this review. It is an instanced adventure game where you play as 3 characters: a child, a business man and an elderly gentleman. Today I decided to give the game a shot in its current state and I have to say, even with the small amount of playable content available, I feel it has a really interesting story to tell.

The first thing to remember is that this game is completely free. The developers aren't forcing potential players to pay any money for the game although they do mention a few times that if you're interested in helping to crowdfund the final product, you can do so here: https://www.eppela.com/projects/5016-the-way-of-life?locale=en

From the moment I laid eyes on this game I have been in love with the art style. The minimalistic theme works especially well with the type of feeling the developers are trying to deliver with their gameplay and it genuinely makes spending time in this game's world very relaxing and atmospheric. It should also be mentioned that the designers of this game were able to pull off this art style for a number of different moods. For example when you're playing as the old gentleman, the game becomes greyscale and gameplay becomes more lethargic, the camera less easily controlled, whereas when you are the child you'll find yourself in colourful environments, able to look and move far more responsively. Small touches like this help to create a far more immersive experience for players.

The Way Of Life's actual gameplay content is lacking. There are only a few scenarios and some  of these areas feel kind of stunted and unpolished. I also feel that the way you transport between levels, whilst seemingly clever at first with the use of non-euclideon looking spaces, is kind of blunt. One moment you're immersed in a wonderful world, finding out all about the character you are currently playing as, the next you are standing in a white room, surrounded by a volley of doors. Jarring to say the least. Another noticible issue that the game's text feels inconsistently written, as if the text was briefly translated from another language into English. On a more positive note, the way the developers expressed the credits to the game was quite unique, dedicating an entire room to a modelled version of each member of the team. When each member is interacted with, their team roles are displayed.

But what is this game trying to do? What is the purpose of this game? According to the developers, this game started as a project for a 48 hour Game Jam where the developers had 2 days to throw together any type of game they could based around the topic, We don't see things as they are

The game basically explains what it is like for a business man, an old man and a young person, in that order

It is at this slow paced period that you notice many small things placed near you - the bench, the fact that if you stop infront of the car for too long, they will drive over you :(  You some how manage to reach your place.
Finally. as a child you see the world as an imaginary wonderland. You fight your way through flying dragon, crossing the river of lava on wooden plank bridge.

The Way Of Life is an Interactive game.

The second character is an elder man.He still sees the dark world they live, but his vision is blurry with the age, and he can't walk as fast or as longer has the Mid age man.He even has to rest from crosswalk to crosswalk.He is so slowly to the society, that the cars barely stop to let him cross the road.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The way of life
I don’t know why this hasn’t received an award for best game of the year because I tell you right now: it deserves it 100%. I’ve honestly played this game for so long now and have not regretted one minute of it. Every minute felt like a complete emotional roller coaster; had my ups and downs with it as it brought a complete emotional experience.

Gameplay
Right, I want to make this completely clear. The graphics in this game are not ‘mind boggling’ in any way. They are just perfect with the whole game genre. This made me personally think about my life. What have I done to contribute to society like this game has? But that’s one side of the story. Now to the actual gameplay; at first it’s anxious and very slow. As time went on I started to get the feel (both physical and mental). The music really makes the game that bit more emotional. When listening to the soundtrack and ambience of the atmosphere you are almost bound to sprout a tear in your eyes. The soundtrack was playing with the string of my heart.

Level 1: You’re a middle aged guy/woman or whatever you want to classify yourself as (That’s what makes this game so good, You are who you are in the game. You make your own character up and you make those around you up as well). The whole objective is to cross a road; by doing so you start to evaluate your surroundings (as you would in real life) and start to gather information about everything. Now by this you might be thinking this is really easy but it’s not! There are people obstructing your path: People almost holding you back from achieving your main goal and this relates to real life; No matter who you are. There will always be someone in your way trying to make you not achieve your goal. After you have crossed the road you will be faced with a building. What makes this building so special is the fact the building is an ordinary building. It has an entrance point (A door obviously) Now when you go through that door. The objective is right in front of you. A few feet away lays another door. What this taught me is that you go through so much to open a door. Close that and you may be closer to opening a new door. In this corridor there are about 5 doors each left and right. The door we want is straight ahead (no options to pick other doors) which is rather good because this is now teaching us that not only do we other options in our faces but we are almost forced to go with an option

Level 2: You’re an old woman/man. Your vision has went statically like an 1990 television not connected to anything. Now this is what really got me. The music has changed to kind of classical. Which really does bring the atmosphere more alive, as of the last level there where a lot of people crossing that road obstructing your path to your main objective. What really makes this emotional is the fact that there is no more people. There are literally 5 or so people at the other end of the road. This teaches us how some people die younger than other. That few people rarely make it to being that old of an age. Now the movement speed the old entity presents to us is very slow. This made me think he has a walking stick because we are the ultimate creators to this creation. Slowly we make it too the zebra. What really broke me is the true fact that 6/9 cars will not stop for old people crossing the road because the sole fact that they’re really slow at crossing the road and some people need to get places. Now we can accept the fact if someone is in a real rush to get somewhere that they can take a sneaky 50mph sprint through a zebra crossing not waiting on an elderly person crossing acceptable. But not 2 thirds of people. So we make the chance after 6 cars have just sprinted their way past. Slowly and steadily I placed the feet of an elderly man onto the zebra crossing and was walking ever so slowly. I just gapped it when the other 3 cars started driving (What also amazes me is this is set in the future as the cars have no acceleration and they can break in a split second. Technology grows on us every day.) By this point we are in the middle of the road which is in fact split by an island of pavements. Enough to have a bench placed in the middle. Now as an old man we have to accept the fact that we will get tired and exhausted pretty quickly. So that is why the bench is placed there. We go and take a nap on the bench for a good 1 minute and can raise up again and go to the next zebra crossing. And again the passive cars theory (which I explained just a bit up) is applied. The futuristic cars theory is also applied (Explained a little bit above). So the 6 cars pass and we take a sprint of faith to make it to that same old building we opened the door up. Which too us is a huge achievement with the length of time it actually took us to make it there. That’s the level complete. What really does get me is the whole truth behind this.

Level 3: You are a little boy/girl. This brings back memories of when I was young and I was full of creativity and imagination. You’re set on an island isolated and surrounded by which seems to be lava. Now to the left of you is another island that is higher above lava level than your island. There is a bridge connecting between the two islands is a bridge. A well build bridge (Brings back the memories of your younger construction days living out in the middle of nowhere. Had to find something to do so building a bridge was a fairly common exercise where I lived). The whole objective was to cross that bridge into into the next island which had a house with the door concealing this huge pink donut. Now this teaches us that basically when you go through so much at the end of it you’re rewarded. Rewarded with a sweet. You may be thinking this will be easy but stop thinking this way: There’s something obstructing our path and almost knocking us off target to eternal oblivion. If we are not careful we will feel pain. Like those bad mistakes you made. Not being patient enough and receiving punishment but with another chance. This really broke me and I almost burst out in tears about this fact but anyway. As we pass the main objective and make it to the new island we are faced with a building and a huge door and as we approach it there is a big spinning donut. At this point we are so happy in life to achieve this goal of getting candy. Then we walk and the game is over.

Conclusion:
The best game ever. 10/10 for me. Thanks

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Way of Life is somewhat troubling to me. A game with a lot of ambition that keeps me endlessly optimistic.. but cautiously optimistic nonetheless. The decisions made for the game are unnerving, but they don't seem like outright bad ideas for the game being made. Or even like cheap or pretentious ideas. Just ideas that seem to point to a cheap and pretentious mind-set of game development, that makes me genuinely concerned, but still kind of open to the idea of this experiment.

Seeing it's transition from three seperate people walking down the same street with different viewpoints of that street, to three comepletely irrelevent stories about those same three people from before seems like a sudden change if not simply inoquous at best. And the personality of these three characters seems out of place from the beta that I played in the beginning.

Gone are the days of childlike innocence, playing adventure down a street to get some ice cream. Now the child is collecting love memorabilia to convince his dad to stop beating his mom. The suited man is now trying to go home from his job, instead of go TO his job, and his nightmare deals with his family in peril on a floating space rock. And the old man dreams of death chasing him down a temple run arena. My point is that this game is worry-some even if it'll all turn out alright. And it doesn't help that they set up a money campaign the moment the game came out.

Although I'm ever curious, I still think this game is worth keeping your eye on.

Early Access Review

Whoa.....

This game clearly has potential, I mean, it has a gaint rotating pastery! That should be a requirement in all games! It has an interesting concept and is quite unique. I enjoyed the different maps and features in each mode (for example you could only jump as a child, or the elderly man had trouble seeing so there was a delay in turning) But there are some things they need to work on before releasing it.

1. The order is mixed up. As a game that is meant simulate the different perspectives we have throughout our life, it should be played in the same way we live our life, Chronological order! Yes the child level is the most exciting, so they left it to the end, but it doesn't have to be! Playing as adult then elder then child just doesn't flow well. Call me picky, but it bothered me. I hope they adjust this when incorperating more levels.

2. For now, it is too easy. The most challanging level was the child level, and that was mainly due to glitches in the game (like towards the end of the bridge the charecter often became stuck). The game does not take that long to beat, due to the limited play area. I hope when they add more levels (I heard there was going to be 20 when all said and done) it makes it a more engrossing experiance.  In addition I agree with other reviewers that there should be hidden components, or at the very least alternate paths one can take (like the stanley parable). After all, life is what we make it, I think including choice in this game could make it one of the greats!

3. The adult level is WAYYY too short. I understand the message behind it (all that an adult is focused on is work, there is nothing else important), but that could be displayed in soooo many ways, they need add more to this level than simply walking into the building, also it is too similar to the elder level.

Overall (despite my critique above) this is a cool little game with a ingenious concept. I hope that once more levels are added and it is released out of early testing it will be even better. I am going to keep an eye on this one and reccomend everyone else does the same!

Play this game and think about yourself and how you view the world around you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a melodrama stretched to the limits, it barely exceeds at anything. The ideas present are somewhat interesting, they've certainly updated the game from the “cross the street and cry over your tragic morality” game that it originally was. Now it's a “Cross through and cry over your tragic morality” game, with a few more features, like more than one to different character models and graphics. Really, it's not a bad game—it's just that I really am ambivalent to the whole thing. Nothing really interests me and nothing really offends me.

I'm also not opposed to the themes or ideas in the game. That melodramatic cry over death stuff actually can be done really well, I'm a huge fan of Ingmar Bergman's The Seventh Seal and Charlie Kaufman's Synedoche, NY, which are are exactly in line with the themes of this game and I love them. But the game itself presents these ideas that I think require a bit more skill in terms of story development and game development. I think there have been games on this subject and I think they've been done better.

Maybe you should give a shot if you really want. It's just that I can't find enjoyment in the game. Perhaps I'm looking in all the wrong places and the people who enjoy it are connected and touched by the game in way I can't possibly understand. I don't know, all in all this game is a very odd one for me, I really don't what to think about it. I just can't recommend it because I don't think I have a lot to say either in favor or against. Most games I can come up with a specific fault but not this one.

I don't know, play it if you want. I just really can't come up with anything. It seems pretentious to me, but some people claim that it made them tear up and there are so many things out there that make me tear up even though people call it pretentious, so I know not to criticize something that affects certain people.

Just do what you will and come up with your own opinion.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game tries to be insightful about how one expiences life during different periods of their life, those being an old man, a middle-aged man, and a child.

The two main differences between these three gameplay segments are the graphics and the controls, which boils down to the kid controlling standardly and seeing pretty colors, the adult controlling the same but significantly slower, and the old man controlling like a drunken toddler.  The graphics also get less colorful as your character ages.  The only thing you do in this game is get from point A to point B, where either imaginary dragons, buisnessmen, or people that need to learn what a crosswalk is, block your path.

The game is only 10 minutes long, and in that 10 minutes, the only food for thought is immensely surface-level.  Yes, I understand that old people are slow and that kids are full of life.  I am fully aware that the color palette's descent into grayness is meant to portray how as one gets older, life becomes a mundane grind.  Like, no duh game, that's common knowledge.  It doesn't matter how stylized you make the graphics, or how you use the gameplay to send a 'message'; those just seem like a veneer to hide how shallow the game is.

Now, this isn't to say that I don't believe that games can't or shouldn't be meaningful, there are quite a few good examples of ones that are, (Bioshock, The Talos Principle, Spec Ops: The Line, etc.) but unlike those games, this one uses its 'meaningful' message to hide how empty it is, to the point where the dev didn't feel the need to animate 90% of the game.  The only think I find interesting is how the gameplay itself portrays a message, but, once again, the message is so surface level that it barely makes a difference, which is a shame since the only other game I can think of that does that is Spec Ops: The Line.

All in all, The Way of Life is a game that uses its poor message to trick people into thinking that it's more important than it is.  It does some unique things, and I hope that other games take notes from it, but don't replicate its flaws in the process.  I think it's a poorly made expirence, even with its short length and nonexistent price tag.  See what you think of it for yourself, but this game is a 3/10 in my book, MAYBE a 4.

Don't waste your time.

DON'T INSTANTLY DISLIKE MY REVIEW BECAUSE ITS NEGATIVE.

JUST DON'T.

Hm... to begin with, its okay. There's nothing to lose atleast, since its free. It's a very short adventure, has a nice art style, although is quite laggy for such limited graphics. It's not that my PC is weak, I've invested about $2000 in it. Besides that, there's not much content. The game is about seeing life through different perspectives. The child lives in fear and tries his best to make things better, but doesn't know how to very well. The bussinessman hates his job, and just wants to be done with it. The old man is easy going, but has his fears as well. I believe it is the same person, but in different times of his life.

The only reason I have 40 minutes in the game instead of 20 is because some of the nightmare levels are rather frustratingly difficult. It doesn't require my thought, only a lot of time on something I'd rather not do. I managed to complete the boy's nightmare, but skipped the bussinessman's nightmare, as it was even more time consuming and the old man's nightmare required you to complete a QTE. However, that QTE will instantly end as you die the moment you stop running. So I skipped that one too. Besides, the ending of the little boy's nightmare was rather weak for all the action that happened before.

I'm assuming there's a deeper meaning under the game's picture, and I have made several observations about what some things mean, like the floating islands outside. I'm guessing that represents that the outside world is unfamiliar, but not scary. Either that, or the creators just wanted to limit the player's roaming space. Neither is bad, it's better than an invisible wall without warning. I preferred the second set of levels much more. You can either choose to satisfy those who have enough, whether it's you or the children with a toy, or to help those that need it more, like the homeless man.

Back to the nightmare levels, it's frustrating that you can only speed up the text that is said, but not the little cutscene and 'start' button itself. There are no checkpoints, and it can glitch out on you.

Overall I wish steam had either a number rating option or an in between" rating. I think you should download it

Dont know what to write, so I will write a recipie for pancakes.

ingredients

100g plain flour
2 eggs
300ml semi-skimmed milk
1 tbsp sunflower oil or vegetable, plus extra for frying
pinch salt

Method

Blending in the flour: Put the flour and a pinch of salt into a large mixing bowl and make a well in the centre. Crack the eggs into the middle, then pour in about 50ml milk and 1 tbsp oil. Start whisking from the centre, gradually drawing the flour into the eggs, milk and oil. Once all the flour is incorporated, beat until you have a smooth, thick paste. Add a little more milk if it is too stiff to beat.
Finishing the batter: Add a good splash of milk and whisk to loosen the thick batter. While still whisking, pour in a steady stream of the remaining milk. Continue pouring and whisking until you have a batter that is the consistency of slightly thick single cream. Traditionally, people would say to now leave the batter for 30 mins, to allow the starch in the flour to swell, but there’s no need.
Getting the right thickness: Heat the pan over a moderate heat, then wipe it with oiled kitchen paper. Ladle some batter into the pan, tilting the pan to move the mixture around for a thin and even layer. Quickly pour any excess batter into a jug, return the pan to the heat, then leave to cook, undisturbed, for about 30 secs. Pour the excess batter from the jug back into the mixing bowl. If the pan is the right temperature, the pancake should turn golden underneath after about 30 secs and will be ready to turn.
Flipping pancakes: Hold the pan handle, ease a fish slice under the pancake, then quickly lift and flip it over. Make sure the pancake is lying flat against base of the pan with no folds, then cook for another 30 secs before turning out onto a warm plate. Continue with the rest of the batter, serving them as you cook or stack onto a plate. You can freeze the pancakes for 1 month, wrapped in cling film or make them up to a day ahead.

TL;DR: The game has a lot of major but fixable problems, both on the narrative and gameplay side of things. Being early access, the developers do have time to address these issues, but at the time being I could not even bring myself to complete the game. Some sections were so easy and linear I felt a tad insulted, while others I'm not even sure are possible to beat. At the moment, I cannot recommend this game, but I hope the game's quality will improve before it's officially launched.

I discovered this game bored in the car a couple months ago. I had nothing better to do so I opened the Steam app on my phone and scrolled through my reccomended." As a huge fan of the whole
recommended:
movement, so naturally I got pumped to play this game, and I added it to my wishlist to remember to play it; and.... I completely forgot about it until today.

I'll get what I like about the game out of the way first: the art style is fantastic, and I absolutely LOVE the CONCEPT of it. I can tell that the developers put a lot of planning into the CONCEPT. It feels thought out, and I can tell they had a passion for the CONCEPT. I'm not sure, however, if the same amount of joyous passion went into the actual game.

The game opens, and you are a disembodied consciousness floating in a circle of doors. 90% of them are blank and do not do anything, but I assume they are placeholders for future levels. The very first thing I noticed was that, office-building grey noise that seems to be present in the overworld of EVERY first person Indie game in the last 3 years. Stanley Parable did it, and it fit the aesthetic of the game well. In this game and almost every other game, it makes no sense. It's such an overused trope at this point, it immediately took me out of the experience. It would've worked a million times better if the soundtrack for the overworld was instead some sort of ambient, godlike seeming melody.

Speaking of immersion breaking as soon as the game starts, the camera starts focused on a huge, out-of-art-style banner ad to support the game on Kickstarter. Ugh. Don't get me wrong, I like crowdfunding. But when your overworld seems designed for the sole purpose of making people give you money, you're doing it wrong.

The world the game takes place in is so unbelievably...lacking. I don't know exactly how to describe it, but everything in it feels so artificial. NPC movements are choppy and on an infinite loop, and dialogue spoken by the protagonists is so handholdy and slap you over the head" with its

But I got used to this: what I could not get used to was the old man character's camera movement speed. It is SOOO much different than that of all of the other characters. I understand it's supposed to make his movements feel older

narrative games, But the actual game parts shoehorned in are poorly done and boring. Quick time events, hidden object puzzles, and floaty platforming add up to make the game frustrating. Also, it needs to make up its mind on whether I can jump or not. Several levels allow me to jump when jumping isn't needed to beat the level, while on others *cough the old man's dream cough* I found impossible since the jump is completely disabled.

I am almost tempted to back the game on Kickstarter, (I'm sure that's at least partially due to their obnoxious and immersion-breaking in-game ad for it) but I don't think throwing money at it will fix the game. I simply think it needs time for the developers to work.

A MESSAGE TO THE DEVELOPERS: as I said earlier, I imagine you are planning to add lots of new content to the game, judging by the overworld. However, I hate to say it, but most of the content already in it is buggy, poorly designed, and written. I LOVE your concept for the game, and I want to see it succeed. But PLEASE remember, small amounts of perfect content is infinitely better than 20 more levels of what you have now. I would legitimately pay 5-10 dollars for this game with the amount content it has now if you were able to fix EVERYTHING I've mentioned here.

I tried this game for about 20 minutes, and in that time experienced more than enough to write this review. Right off the bat, one of the first things you will notice, is that the english in this game is pretty bad. While this is easily over-looked, it is still very annoying when setting the room. Now to describe the game itself!

This game uses a hub setting where all the levels are set in different rooms, each of which gives you several different scenarios. After entering the room you can choose whether to experience it as a child, adult, or senior citizen. This dynamic in itself is very focused on plot, but is used in a game which... has no plot? A questionable choice, but not a deal breaker. The real deal breaker is what happens after: Nothing! Let me explain. After choosing the scenario you will be teleported to the area you chose, as the character you chose. From there you can walk around and experience the situation. Often times it is pretty bland and lacking, and the couple of sentences used to describe it into a sensible situation are poorly written.

At this point it probably seems like a game with a poor setting, and their are tons of enjoyable games like that, but that isn't the bad part. The main thing that ruins this game is that it's pointless. After entering the scenario you walk, or fly, or whatever it asks. It feels very boring and unrewarding, and after doing it for about 2 or 3 minutes you hit a dead end. And that's it. There is nothing beyond that. All you can do is return to the hub from the main menu, and try a different scenario.

The gameplay consists entirely of walking, but unlike slender-man and other great walking games, there is no point to this one. The entire game is designed around a poorly written, meaningless story, that can't really even be called a story.

On top of everything it is extremely buggy as well, just FYI

So you have a game that:
-Doesn't play well
-Is glitchy
-Poorly designed
-Confuses the player with lack of instruction
-Is POINTLESS and MEANINGLESS

Now I'm not trying to hate on the game itself or its creator, I'm just stating facts. Assuming this was made by a single developer, or maybe a small group of rookies, it's actually a pretty good attempt. However, you can't just turn anything into a game. You need to put some forethought into it. Checking you writing is also very important, and this game clearly didn't go through any of the essential checkpoints of game design. Avoid if at all possible.

chocolate Chip Cookie Dough Brownies
Ingredients:

BROWNIE LAYER:
3/4 cup (1 1/2 sticks) unsalted butter
1 1/2 cups bittersweet chocolate chips
1 cup granulated white sugar
1/2 cup packed light brown sugar
4 large eggs
1 teaspoon vanilla extract
1/2 teaspoon salt
1 cup all-purpose flour

COOKIE DOUGH:
3/4 cup (1 1/2 sticks) unsalted butter, room temperature or almost melted
3/4 cup granulated white sugar
3/4 cup packed light brown sugar
1/4 teaspoon salt
2 tablespoons milk or cream
1 1/2 teaspoons vanilla extract or vanilla bean paste
1 cup all-purpose flour
1 cup miniature chocolate chips
additional miniature chocolate chips, if desired (to garnish the top)
Directions:

Prepare the brownie layer-
1. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F. Spray a 9x9-inch pan with nonstick spray, then line with a strip of parchment paper so that it covers the bottom and comes up two sides of the pan. Spray the parchment with nonstick spray too.
2. In a microwave safe bowl (or in the top of a double boiler or pan set on top of a pan of simmering water), microwave in 30 second bursts to melt butter and chocolate chips together until all is melted and smooth. Whisk in the sugars, then whisk in the eggs, vanilla and salt. Sift flour into the bowl and stir that in too. Scrape the brownie batter into the prepared pan. Bake for 25 to 30 minutes, or until the brownie layer is cooked through (toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean). Place the pan of brownies in the refrigerator to speed up the cooling process (or cool at room temperature and add the cookie dough layer later).

Prepare the cookie dough layer:
3. In a large bowl, use an electric mixer to combine the butter, sugars and salt until soft and creamy (1 to 2 minutes). Mix in the milk and vanilla. Sprinkle in the flour and mix in until combined. Stir in the 1 cup of chocolate chips. Scoop the cookie dough onto the top of the brownies and spread onto the brownie layer. I find that it's easiest to do this if the brownie layer is chilled and firm. Wet your hands or spray them with nonstick spray and pat the cookie dough on top in a even layer. Sprinkle additional chocolate chips on top to create a nicer, visual appearance. For easy, clean cutting, chill the brownies (wrap the brownies with plastic wrap and chill until firm- 1 to 2 hours or up to 2 days).
4. Cut the brownies: Run a knife along the sides of the brownie pan and then use the parchment paper to lift the brownies from the pan and onto a cutting board. Slice the brownies with a sharp knife, wiping the knife with a paper towel between cuts. If you'd like all of your slices of brownies to look clean-cut without edges, use the knife to cut the sides of the brownies off before cutting pieces. Keep brownies slices covered and chilled until ready to serve.

I have no idea how this game has 79% positive reviews. The gameplay is boring, the text is disjointed and is extremely lacking in gramma, and the music is the most repetitive thing I have ever heard.

The character animations are atrocious and are just tiny snippets being played on loop. The result is a shoddy and awful look. I understand that the game has a certain art style - and I do enjoy how the visuals of this game are - but the lack of effort for animations makes the world feel boring as hell.

The gameplay is horrible and I feel like it's a long chore just to play this game. Everything is just walking and pressing E on objects to do things, with very little guidance along the way. Your characters also move slower than a tortoise with a broken leg, which I can understand might be intentional for the 'old' character, but it's still not a fun game to play.

It is apparent to me that the developers do not speak English as their first language. This wouldn't be a problem if the message of the game relied a lot on the text. 'I'm so tired my oldness' is one phrase used in the game. Seriously? 'Why my parents put me to bed' is another, and there are quite a few spelling mistakes that I have noticed.

The game is lacking in content. There are only two sets of levels which is pretty poor seeing that the game has been released on steam for over a year now. A six man development team is also a pretty large team for such a small game, and I would expect faster content to be made.

The message of this game? Eh, it's alright. They're extremely stereotypical. The kid is afraid of a monster. The adult is afraid of losing his family. The elderly man is afraid of dying. It's not at all fun to play. The nightmare levels are atrocious and are literally just walking away from evil thing. The other levels involve walking around a town, and trying to stop your parents from fighting. The horrible presentation of the game completely removes the good part of the game.

It's also annoying how the developers are constantly shoving the crowfounding things in my face. The game is poor quality and very unfinished.

If there was one good thing I could say about the game, it's that the art style is nice. That's about all the praise I can give. Horrible gameplay, lackluster message, the most repetitive music imaginable, and a complete lack of polish.

Don't waste your time playing this half-♥♥♥♥♥ creation.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is based on an interesting concept, how children, adults, and the elderly think about life differently.
Unfortunately, nearly all of your time with the game is spent wandering around revisiting the same areas to try and figure out where you are supposed to go. Even the main menu takes a while to understand because it involves walking around an empty space and going into rooms to select what you want.

The game may have a deep premise but you can't think too hard about it because of all the dull gameplay you have to complete. Finding where to go and doing a scavenger hunt would be more fun if the world was more interesting and your movement speed was a bit faster.

Anyway, some people might enjoy this game but I really feel like it was a chore to complete.

(Also, I'm not sure what is up with the official Steam videos for this game. One video spoils 2/3 of the game and shows exactly where to go, while the other video shows some levels that were never available for me to play)

17/05/15
Well, for a game with about 5 minutes of content and no storyline, it actually comes across as a very well structured and thought through game.

Here's how it goes: You launch it and get given a snippet based on the character you choose. To start with, you play as a middle-aged man with a job in an office. Next you are an elderly man following the same route that your younger self did, only a little bit differently. Finally you play as a young boy. What's interesting is that the boy's snippet is the most different out of the three. While it didn't bring a tear to my eye, it certainly made me think of how peoples lives change as they grow up. Do yourself a favour and try it. Don't like the game? You've only lost five minutes of your life so no big deal, but I reckon you're foolish to say it didn't at least make you think on it.

Pros:
+Excellent story (or lack there of, it's your choice)

Cons:
-The camera movement feels a bit sluggish
-Lack of content currently (as it is Early Access, expect this to change)
